title: Jamie Carragher and Gary Neville blast 'disgraceful' Southampton after Leicester loss
text:
Nathan Redmond apologises to Southampton supporters after their 9-0 defeat to Leicester (Picture: Getty)

Jamie Carragher labelled Southampton’s players a ‘disgrace’ following their dismal 9-0 defeat to Leicester City on Friday night while Gary Neville said that he sees parallels between the Saints and Sunderland.

Southampton were on the receiving end of the joint-heaviest defeat in the Premier League era and the worst-ever loss at home as a rampant Leicester City made their extra man pay emphatically at St Mary’s.

Ben Chilwell’s goal and Ryan Bertrand’s sending off after ten minutes put Southampton in trouble and they utterly capitulated as Ayoze Perez and Jamie Vardy helped themselves to hat-tricks with Youri Tielemans and James Maddison also on the scoresheet.

A despondent Ralph Hassenhuttl said after the game that he accepted all responsibility for the defeat but Carragher insisted that the players had to take their share of the blame after a spineless display.

Saints boss Ralph Hassenhuttl took full responsibility for the defeat (Picture: Getty)

Speaking on Friday Night Football, Carragher said: ‘He [Hassenhuttl] said ‘I’m taking all responsibility. Take the responsibility off the manager, Listen, the manager will stand and fall by results, but there’s no way [after] a 9-0 and that performance I’m going to point the finger at the manager.

‘Some of those players there were a disgrace really and people think about the extra man in football… what it does it means its very difficult to go and win a game, it doesn’t mean you can’t stop the opposition winning a game.

‘Now I know it was 1-0 at the time [of Bertrand’s sending off] but there’s no way that shouldn’t just finish 3-0. We’ve been there ourselves, we’ve had the extra man, we’ve been down to ten men it happens a lot in the Premier League, but you don’t see 9-0.’

He added: ‘Even at the start of the second half, Jamie Vardy had another good chance and you’re thinking ‘where is the backbone in this team?’ An absolutely disgraceful performance that will reverberate around the Premier League.’

The result plunged Southampton into the relegation zone and Neville suggested that the club could find itself following Sunderland’s path after their fans departed St Mary’s en masse as Leicester piled on the misery.

‘I always think its a worry – and looking at it from a director’s box point of view – when the stadium is empty. We saw at Sunderland for a period when they were losing badly,’ Neville said.

‘These fans here, I’ve always thought of them as being really friendly and fans that would always stay with the team but tonight they were booing them at half-time, booing them at the end, most of them left anyway.

‘It was a terrible night anyway but the stadium must have five or six thousand people in it by the end.’
